text:
General View: Manhattan Columbus Street, between Broadway and Centre Street showing Barnums Museum opened in 1810, where court House now stands and view looking northwards on Broadway.

About 1850.

Vesey - Battery Pk.

Broadway, north from Park Row, showing buildings on the westerly side facing City Hall Park. This civic area lies between these two thoroughfares, being at the apex formed by their convergence. At the left margin is a portion of the old Astor House, this being the S.W. corner of Barclay Street. The block front above (to Park Place) was the site of the Woolworth Building in 1912.

About 1860's

87 Nassau St., N.Y.C

title: Manhattan: Broadway - Park Row

text:
Broadway, south from Vesey (right) and Ann (left) Streets, showing prominently the Western Union Building and the spire of Trinity Church. In the right foreground is a portion of the Astor House, facing St. Pauls Chapel. On the extreme left appears the entrance to the New York Herald Building.

1880.

Brown Brothers.

Broadway, south from Vesey (right) and Ann (left) Streets, showing prominently the Western Union Building and the spire of Trinity Church. On the right (foreground) appears a portion of the old Astor House facing St. Pauls Chapel.

1880.

Brown Brothers.

Broadway, west side, south from and including Vesey, to and including Dey Streets, showing a portion of the Astor House, St. Pauls P.E. Chapel and the Western Union Building. On the extreme left appears a portion of the New York Herald Building (part of present site of St. Paul Building).

About 1880.

Broadway & Park Row, north from their convergence at Vesey Street, showing the old U. S. Post Office at the apex of City Hall Park . Note the completion or roof repairs. At the left is the Astor House, occupying the Broadway frontage from Vesey to Barclay Street's..

About 1880

Gift of Urbrock Collection
title: Manhattan: Broadway - Park Row

text:
Broadway , south from City Hall Park. On the right is the Post Office; on the left the Benjamin Franklin Statue
1890's
title: Manhattan: Park Row - City Hall Park

text:
Park Row, south from the Brooklyn Bridge, to and including Broadway. The view shows in the foreground, the new (then) pedestrian approach to the Brooklyn Bridge Station of the Second and Third Aves., Elevated. Adjoining same is the Pulitzer Building, with the spire of the Tribune Building overshadowing the Times Building, on the right. In the distant background, at the southern extremity of Park Row, at Broadway, is observed St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel. Directly on the right, is the Hall of Records, built as a City Jail about 1775.

About 1880.
title: Manhattan: Park Row - Broadway

text:
Park Row, south from the Brooklyn Bridge, to and including Broadway. The view shows on the extreme right, the old Hall of Records, with the City Hall further westward. In the direct center, is the old U.S.P.O., with the Times Building on the opposite side of the street. At the head of Park Row, at Broadway, appears St. Paul's Church and Grounds. Note the horse drawn cars. Bridge shown, in the foreground, was an extension from the Brooklyn Bridge Station of the Manhattan Elevated Lines.

About 1884.

New York Edison Co.
title: Manhattan: Park Row - Broadway

text:
(1) Broadway, North West corner, Barclay to Vesey Streets, and showing the old Astor House, since demolished and St. Paul's Chapel.
(2) The same, closer view.
About 1885.
Urbrock Collection,
May not be reproduced.

Broadway, West Side, between Barclay and Vesey Streets, showing the old Astor House.

About 1885.

Urbrock Collection,

Broadway, south from Barclay Street (right), showing cables being laid on the east side of this thoroughfare and slightly north of the Astor House, which appears on the right. South of the latter is St. Pauls Chapel. On the left is a portion of the Post Office, at the convergence of Broadway and Park Row. Across the latter are structures on the east side of same, at Ann Street.

About 1890.

Broadway, west side, north from Vesey Street, showing prominently the old Astor House, built 1832, occupying the entire block frontage to Barclay Street. Early records inform us that this site was an encampment for negro slaves in 1780. Numbers of these died of smallpox and were buried where the Sun (formerly A. T. Stewart) Building stands at the N. E. corner of Broadway and Chambers Street. The Woolworth Building was erected in 1912 and the Transportation Building in 1926. The latter at the far corner, while the former in the block above.

About 1890

Thru New York Historical

Broadway, west side, at Barclay Street, showing the sites of the future Transportation and Woolworth Bldgs. The former rose in 1926 at the S. W. corner that now is the northerly half of the old Astor House. The several structures at the right forming the block frontage from Barclay Street to Park Place will be removed in 1912 for the distinctive Woolworth Building.

About 1890

Roege, photo
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

(1)
Broadway, west side, north from Vesey (left) to Barclay (right) Streets, showing the Astor House, built in 1832 and opened in 1836 by Boyden, a hotel keeper from Boston. It was reopened September 1, 1875 by F.J. Allan and A.J. Dunn. The portion at the N.W. corner of Vesey Street was demolished and is today (1937) the site of the Astor Building; No. 217 Broadway. On this site in 1780 there was an encampment of Negro slaves, enticed by Lord Dunmore from Virginia. Large numbers died from small pox and were buried in the ground later occupied by Stewarts (Department Store) at Chambers Street and Broadway.

Date----?

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)
The same, at a later date and showing a more extensive view to and including Park Place. Note the portion of the Astor House still standing. This was taken down in March 1926 and there upon was erected the 44-story Transportation Building, No. 225 Broadway, at the S.W. corner of Barclay Street. The Woolworth Building occupies the block between Barclay Street and Park Place.

May 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3)
A similar view, slightly more inclusive northward.
About 1890.

August Loeffler
P. L. Sperr.

Large numbers died from small pox and were buried in the ground later occupied by Stewarts (Department Store) at Chambers Street and Broadway.

Across the nave of the Chapel appears buildings that line the south side of Fulton Street, west from Broadway to Church Street. Note the horse drawn cars in the foreground, a junction point of several lines.

About 1891.

Broadway, west side, from Vesey to Barclay Street's, showing the old Astor House, as photographed from the St. Paul Building.

About 1895

Broadway, north from Vesey Street (left, not shown). Detailed from left to right are, the Astor House, the Postal Telegraph and the Home Life Insurance Co. Bldgs., the Shoe & Leather Bank, the Sun Bldg. (formerly A. T. Stewarts) and the old U. S. General Post Office. The latter is at the apex formed by the convergence of Park Row with Broadway at this point. This photo is an enlargement from an original lantern slide.

About 1895-7)

Gift of Russell Freeman
New York Public Library

220 Broadway, at the S. E. corner of Ann Street, showing the 25 storied St. Paul Building. On the left is an eastward view on Ann Street, from Park Row, an arterial thoroughfare that begins at this point. Note the ornate National Park Bank at the right. This is obstructed by a corner of St. Pauls Chapel.

Copyright 1897

text:
Broadway, west side, from Vesey to Barclay Streets, showing the old Astor House, erected in 1832. The far corner of this site will be utilized for the 44 story Transportation Building in 1926. In 1912 in the block above will rise the towering Woolworth Building. At the right margin appears a glimpse of this site.

About 1900

International News Service
Gift of Urbrock Collection
REPRODUCTION RIGHTS UNKNOWN

Broadway, north from near Vesey Street, showing more of the west side of the thoroughfare, On the extreme left is part of the old Astor House. The block front just north of it was repraced later with the Woolworth Building.

, about 1900

City Hall Park: The Nathan Hale statue located in the westerly portion; the Broadway side and viewed northeastward towards Park Row. To the left is the City Hall, to the right, the Tribune Building and in the center background, the Pulitzer (World) Building.

King's Handbook of New York of 1893, page 184 states that this statue by MscMonnies is to be erected here by the Sons of the Revolution.

MacMonnies exhibited this in the Paris Salon of 1891 and was awarded a second gold medal, this being the first time an American sculptor had attained this honor.

Note the subway construction in the midground. Evidently the City Hall station and loop of the I.R.T. is in progress.

1900-01

Gift of Urbrock Collection
title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - N. Hale statue.

City Hall Park:  The subway Kiosk on the northwesterly portion of the Mall that extends thru same from Broadway to Park Row.  At the right is the west wing of the City Hall.  To the left is Chambers Street with the Stewart Building (Sun) and the County House.
1903
title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - [Subway kiosk.]

text:
Broadway, west side, south from and including Barclay (foreground) to Dey (extreme left) Streets, showing prominently the Astor House, which occupies the block between Barclay and Vesey Streets. South of same, on the Vesey to Fulton Streets block, appears St. Pauls P.E. Chapel and Grounds. The spired structure, in the same direction is the 11-story Western Union Building, No. 195 Broadway, at the N.W. corner of Dey Street. Shown on the right are Nos. 229 and 231 Broadway, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of Barclay Street.

June 3, 1904.

Brown Brothers.

Broadway, west side, from Vesey to Barclay Streets, showing the old Astor House.

about 1905

City Hall Park: The Nathan Hale statue by MacMonnies, viewed eastward from Broadway and silhouetted against a background consisting of the City Hall. To the right is the Pulitzer (World) Building located on Park Row, the easterly fringe of the Park.

About 1905

title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - [N. Hale statue.]

text:
Broadway, south from Barclay Street, showing this thoroughfare below City Hall Park. At the right is the old Astor House, occupying the frontage from Barclay to Vesey Street's. In the block below, Vesey to Fulton St's., is St. Pauls Chapel. The old Evening Mail and the towering Singer Building overshadow these. On the left is the St. Paul Building on the old P. T. Barnum site. Park Row converges with Broadway at this point; transportation is provided by the Third Avenue R. R. Co. on this artery, and a street car of same appears thereupon.

About 1910

Gift of Urbrock Collection

title: Woolworth Bldg. iron work, Broadway and Barclay St

text:
Broadway, west side, from Barclay Street to Park Place, showing the Woolworth Building at this location. Note the constructional details atop the tower in both views. The smaller view is obviously in a northward direction from the old Western Union Building and includes the spire of St. Pauls Chapel and the old Astor House in the foreground. At the right is the old U.S. Post Office with a glimpse of the City Hall above same. The 13 story Emigrant Industrial Bank rises above the latter.

1912-3

International News Service
(larger view)

229-237 Broadway, west side, from Barclay Street to Park place, showing at this location, the 55 story Woolworth Bldg. The general direction is northward from a vantage point at No. 165 Broadway (City Investing Bldg.) in views 1, 2, and 3. View 4 is photographed from No. 30 Church Street. Broadway is the thoroughfare clearly shown at the right. Note the spire of St. Pauls Chapel, the quadrangular Astor House, the ornate Post Office, City Hall Park and the white marble Sun (formerly A. T. Stewarts) Building. The St. Paul Bldg. appears at the right margin of views 1 and 3. Today, (1939) this view is more or less the same. The most radical change is the replacement of the old Astor House by the 44 storied Transportation Bldg. and the present demolition of the Post Office.

View 1  March 1912
View 2  June 1912
View 3  January 19, 1917  NEG. # 4624
View 4  August 11, 1925  NEG. # 4618

Gift of W. A. Lucas

Broadway, west side, from Vesey to Barclay Streets, showing the Astor House (erected in 1832). The view is southward from Barclay Street. The foreground half of this building site will be improved with the 44story Transportation Building in 1926.

Broadway, west side, from Vesey to Barclay Streets, showing the old Astor House of 1832. To the right is a glimpse of the Woolworth Building in the block above.

1913

H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

Broadway, at the N. W. corner of Vesey Street, showing the southerly half of the old Astor House demolished. A new 7-story Astor Building was erected here. The remaining half will subsequently be removed for the 44-storied Transportation Building. Beyond is the base of the Woolworth Building. On the right appears the old Post Office. This is at the apex of City Hall Park that is formed by the convergence of Park Row at Broadway. In 1939 this structure was removed and the park restored to its original form.

November 1, 1913

Gift of Urbrock Collection

text:
A general view eastward from the Woolworth Building, 229-237 Broadway, west side, from Barclay Street to Park Place. View shows the interlacing slum sections; Cherry Hill, Corlears Hook etc. of lower Manhattan and Greenpoint, Gowanus Canal, Navy Basin, Williamsburg, etc. of Brooklyn, with the Brooklyn, Manhattan and East River Bridges connecting them.

About 1920.

Brown Brothers.
title: General view - Broadway - East.

original_title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street to Murray Street.
text:
Broadway, west side, north from but not including Vesey to Murray Streets, showing on the extreme left a 7 story structure that replaced a part of the old Astor House. North of same and at the S. W. corner of Barclay Street remains another portion. This latter was replaced by the 44 story Transportation Building. Appearing as a background for these buildings are the lower stories of the Woolworth Building. On the left, at the convergence of Broadway and Park Row is the old U. S. Post Office.

1923.

Brown Bros.

Park Row, east side, north from but not including Ann, to and including Beekman Streets. A portion of the General Post Office is seen in the left foreground.

About 1923.

text:
.12 to 30 Vesey Street, north side, west from, but not including Broadway (right), to Church Street (left).

June 1926.

Brown Bros.

A general view westward on Vesey Street from Broadway, as seen from the St. Paul Building (Broadway at the S.E. corner of Ann Street) and showing the spire of St. Pauls P.E. Chapel silhouetted against the cemetery and Trinity offices at its rear. Prominently shown is the New York Telephone Co. Building (West Street) of which appears the Washington Street side. Dimly observable is the New Jersey shore as seen across the Hudson (North) River. Note the five story loft buildings standing between the Sixth Ave. (Church Street) and Ninth Ave. (Greenwich Street) elevated and overshadowed by the Underwood Building. Today (1937) the downtown United States Post Office rises on this site.

September 1926.

Brown Brothers.

Broadway, west side, south from Vesey (right) to Fulton (left) Streets, showing St. Pauls P.E. Chapel as viewed southwestward on Park Row (foreground). This is a set of 3 views; 1 and 2 being similar, while No. 3 is in a northwestern direction from Fulton Street.

City Hall Park is at the left. Flanking the dominant structure are, the World, the Tribune and the Park Row buildings. The old U. S. Post Office building is obstructed from view.

Broadway (left) and Park Row (right) above Vesey Street, showing the old General Post Office and Federal Bldg. on the day demolition actually started on the outside. This structure, erected about 63 years ago at a cost of 8,500, 000 is to be removed to allow City Hall Park to return to its original contour. For a photo of same from the same point of vantage (The N. Y. Telephone & Telegraph Bldg.) see files under City Hall Park.

Broadway, west side, from Vesey Street (left) to Park Place (right), as viewed across City Hall Park, from the Municipal Building. In the center is Barclay Street. This separates the Transportation Building from the dominant Woolworth Building. Vesey Street performs this function for the vague St. Paul Chapel and the Astor Building.

April 1940

George D. Chinn

City Hall Park as photographed northeastward from the 24th floor of the New York Telephone & Telegraph Bldg. Shown is the newly added portion at the apex of this triangular civic zone. This was until recently the site of the old Post Office and Federal Bldg. The fountain-statue "Civic Virtue" by MacMonnies still stands in front of the City Hall. This is to be removed to Queens and placed near the new Borough Hall. Note the old "Tweed" County Court House, the new Hall of Records, and the base of the Municipal Bldg. in the background. Broadway is on the left while on the right is Park Row.

July 2, 1940

Robert A. Knudtsen
221 E. 31st St., N.Y.C.

Broadway - North from Park Row showing the Post Office on the right.

A Set of Seven Canvases of Old New York

These paintings come from a country house called 'Glencairn' near Dublin in Ireland, where they adorned the walls of the billiard room. The house was built by Richard 'Boss' Croker (1841-1922), an Irishman who for many years was associated with Tammany Hall in New York, holding political positions under William M. 'Boss' Tweed, and later, after the latter's ousting, under 'Honest John' Kelly. Following the Lexow Committee investigations (1889-90), he left for England where he took up residence in Wantage, Berks, returning to America periodically, attempting to regain his lost position in the Democratic Party. After his final defeat in 1900, he crossed the Atlantic once again, built 'Glencairn' and started a racing stable. Despite his past reputation (he paid, in all, $550,000 for his Irish estates), he lived up to the high standards demanded by British racing circles, and when his horse Orby won the Derby in 1907, did not even own him.

These pictures were painted to remind him of New York, and it is assumed that they were executed here around the turn of the century. All are painted in tones of sepia and green.

The British Government has recently acquired this mansion for the use of the British Ambassador to Ireland.

PARKE-BERNET Sale 2234, Nov. 29-30, 1963
